His writing has appeared in the New York Times Magazine, Granta, n+1, and Harpers, and in 2010, he was named one of the New Yorker‘s “20 under 40.” He is Executive Producer of Radio Ambulante, and teaches at the Columbia University School of Journalism in New York.

Buy a copy of One Life or a $15 gift card in store to attend this event.
title: David Lida + Daniel Alarcón

description:
From the Wooster Collective archive and showcase for street art comes a brand-new collection, Eleven Spring: A Celebration of Street Art. Documenting the three-day exhibition at 11 Spring Street, curated by Wooster Collective cohorts Sara and Marc Schiller, it's a monument to a colorful and chaotic takeover that drew crowds in the thousands to witness the power of street art. Join Sara and Marc, along with fellow NYC artists Patrick McNeil and Patrick Miller (of the FAILE collaboration, exhibited in the Tate Modern and elsewhere around the world), for a signing and celebration of this vibrant paean to the explosive power of street art! Also joining the signing, we're honored to have Michael DeFeo and WK Interact.

Please Note: The artists will only sign copies of Eleven Spring purchased at Strand--no copies from other stores (or Amazon). In order to participate in the signing, please reserve your copy or purchase it at the event.

Copies of Eleven Spring will be available for purchase at the event, which will take place in the photography section on the second floor of the Strand at 828 Broadway (at 12th Street).
title: Eleven Spring: A Celebration of Street Art

description:
Cleve Jones has been an activist since the 70s. He worked as a student intern for Harvey Milk and even earned a portrayal in Gus Van Sant's 2008 biopic Milk. Cleve also co-founded the San Francisco AIDS Foundation and came up with the idea of the AIDS Memorial Quilt. His work isn’t done yet as he continues to fight for equality, currently working with UNITE HERE, the hotel, restaurant, and garment workers' labor union on issues of homophobia. Now he has taken some time to write about his life as an activist in his memoir When We Rise: My Life in the Movement.

Cleve will be joined by Editor in Chief at Out Magazine, Aaron Hicklin.

 

Buy a copy of When We Rise or a $15 gift card in-store at the Strand's main floor registers or at the door to attend. This event will take place in the Rare Book Room on the Strand's 3rd floor, accessible via the store elevator or at 826 Broadway.
title: Cleve Jones

description:
Journalist, author, and broadcaster at The Times, Caitlin Moran is a powerhouse. Each week she writes for three columns: a magazine, a TV review, and a satirical column called "Celebrity Watch" where she addresses the big issues such as which famous millionaire couples are splitting. You know, the real issues.

This new collection features her favorite, and award-winning, columns along with three new pieces, all crafted together with a smooth narrative thread. They range from serious to silly and cover topics like poverty, politics, and the internet.

Buy a copy of Moranifesto or a $15 gift card in-store at the Strand's main floor registers or at the door to attend. This event will take place in the Rare Book Room on the Strand's 3rd floor, accessible via the store elevator or at 826 Broadway.
title: Caitlin Moran

description:
Anne Rice, beloved author of thirty-five books including the classic Interview with the Vampire and Prince Lestat, celebrates the release of her latest work of fiction with a public signing. She'll be at the Strand to sign copies of Prince Lestat and the Realms of Atlantis on the book's release date!

Please Note: Anne will sign ONLY copies of Prince Lestat and the Realms of Atlantis that have been purchased at Strand. Photos will not be permitted. The line for this signing will begin forming at 12:30 PM on the day of the event in front of the Strand on Broadway at 12th Street.

Customers may also bring (or buy) one additional Anne Rice book for her to sign.

"In my dreams, I saw a city fall into the sea. I heard the cries of thousands. I saw flames that outshone the lamps of heaven. And all the world was shaken . . ." --Anne Rice, Prince Lestat and the Realms of Atlantis

Buy a copy of Prince Lestat and the Realms of Atlantis in-store at the Strand's main floor registers to have it signed. The line for the signing will form on Broadway in front of the Strand at 12th Street at 12:30 PM.
title: Anne Rice Signs Prince Lestat and the Realms of Atlantis

description:
A long time ago in a galaxy right here, Princess Leia first graced the silver screen. She has since grown into an icon, being turned into decorative figurines and Halloween costumes. Recently, the infamous Carrie Fisher found the journals she had kept during the filming of on the most legendary movies of all time: Star Wars.

Featuring excerpts from her handwritten journals from a pre-star teen as well as new views from a larger-than-life celebrity, The Princess Diarist invites readers into the joys and absurdities of Hollywood stardom. Join us at the main floor’s Buying Desk for a book signing!

The line for this event will start at 5:30pm in front of Strand on Broadway. Upon checking in with staff, you will receive a wristband. Upon entering the store, you will exchange the wristband for your book. A few things to note:

  1. No posed photos with Carrie will be permitted, only photos from the line. 
  2. She will only sign copies of The Princess Diarist purchased at Strand Book Store; no purchases from other stores will be permitted. One book per person (with the exception of children under 12 travelling with adult supervision).
  3. Carrie will not sign memorabilia. 
  4. Strand staff will cut off the line at 8:45pm to ensure that the signing is wrapped up on time. 
  5. The maximum number of books per person is 5.
  6. The line will mostly be outdoors-- dress warmly!
  7. All rules outlined above are subject to change based on the needs of the event. 

Buy a copy of The Princess Diarist in-store at the Strand's main floor registers or at the door to attend. The line for the signing will form on Broadway in front of the Strand at 12th Street at 5:30 PM.
title: Carrie Fisher: The Princess Diarist

description:
Johnny Cash, one of the most influential and iconic musicians in American culture, with a distinct and memorable voice. His songs are poetic and span several musical genres, making it so people of all walks of life know his tunes. Now there’s even more to love with this collection of previously unreleased poems and song lyrics.

Edited by award-winning poet Paul Muldoon and with a foreword from singer-songwriter, and son of the late Johnny Cash, John Carter Cash, the words of Johnny Cash confirm him as a strong literary figure. Join us in the Rare Book Room as John and Paul talk about this new collection, about ‘The Man in Black’, and then sign copies of the book.

John and Paul will be joined by Steve Berkowitz, multi Grammy Award winning producer and musician. He worked with Johnny Cash on the release of the Box Set LOVE, GOD & MURDER and supervised or Co-Produced many other Johnny Cash music releases including; Johnny Cash THE COMPLETE COLUMBIA ALBUM COLLECTION; The Johnny Cash BOOTLEG SERIES Volumes 1 – 4; the album OUT AMONG THE STARS along with John Carter Cash. Along with John Carter Cash, Steve researched and developed Johnny Cash Forever Words.

Buy a copy of Forever Words or a $15 gift card in-store at the Strand's main floor registers or at the door to attend. This event will take place in the Rare Book Room on the Strand's 3rd floor, accessible via the store elevator or at 826 Broadway.
title: John Carter Cash + Paul Muldoon + Steve Berkowitz

description:
The Writers Studio Celebrates The Pushcart Prize and the release of Pushcart Prize XLI: Best of the Small Presses 2017 with readings by fiction writers Charles Baxter (There’s Something I Want You To Do) and Salvatore Scibona (The End), and poets Patricia Spears Jones (Painkilling, A Lucent Fire) and Sally Wen Mao (Mad Honey Symposium), among others. Pushcart Prize's founder and editor Bill Henderson will introduce the evening.

Buy a copy of Pushcart Prize XLI or a $15 gift card in-store at the Strand's main floor registers or at the door to attend. This event will take place in the Rare Book Room on the Strand's 3rd floor, accessible via the store elevator or at 826 Broadway.
title: The Pushcart Prize XLI

description:
Award-winning photographer Steve McCurry has travelled the world capturing powerful and breath-taking images with his cameras. He is most widely known for his 1984 photograph "Afghan Girl" which originally appeared in National Geographic and was named "the most recognized photograph" in the history of the magazine.

In this latest collection of photographs Steve captures the beauty of reading, presenting it in all of it’s glory featuring all types of people from around the world. Join us in the Art Department on the second floor for a book signing. Steve will sign up to three back-list copies of his books per person.

Copies of On Reading will be available for purchase at the event, which will take place in the photography section on the second floor of the Strand at 828 Broadway (at 12th Street).
title: Steve McCurry

description:
Macbeth may have been written in the 1600s, but the dark stories it shares seem eerily relevant to today's world. From a fear and hatred of women, to steering a country into chaos, we have a lot to learn from the Scottish play.

Join us in our Rare Book Room as we examine Macbeth in a new and modern light, relating him and his actions to current events and horrifying social shifts. This class will be led by professor and author Dr. Geoff Klock.

Purchase your tickets in advance HERE or at the door on Monday night.
title: ThinkOlio: Macbeth: Toxic Masculinity, Misogyny, & Monarchy

description:
Join us for this special signing opportunity as Cary Elwes, beloved actor and author signs the recent New York Times Best Seller As You Wish: Inconceivable Tales from the Making of The Princess Bride!

Please Note: The line will begin forming at 5:00 PM on the day of the event in front of the store on Broadway. 

No candid photos are permitted, only posed. Cary will only sign the paperback of As You Wish. He will not do inscriptions other than the customer's name. He will not sign photos or memorabilia.

Buy a copy of As You Wish in-store at the Strand's main floor registers or at the door to attend. The line for the signing will form on Broadway in front of the Strand at 12th Street at 5:00 PM.
title: Cary Elwes: As You Wish

description:
Journalist and Washington Post reporter Wesley Lowery covers law enforcement, justice, and the Black Lives Matter movement, studying the numbers, seeing any connections, and becoming an expert on police shootings. His tracking of these crimes has revealed unnerving statistics on the rate of fatalities.

Wesley has written for the Boston Globe, The Los Angeles Times, The Wall Street Journal, and the Columbus Dispatch. He has been published in the New York Times, The Wall Street Journal, the Boston Globe and several online publications.

Join us in the Rare Book Room as Wesley discusses these important issues with Nikole Hannah Jones from NY Times Magazine. After the discussion Wesley will be signing copies of his book.

This event is free to attend.  Copies of They Can't Kill Us All will be available at the event, which takes place in the Rare Book Room, on the 3rd floor of the store at 828 Broadway.
title: Free Talk: They Can't Kill Us All by Wesley Lowery

description:
Join former Poet Laureate Robert Pinsky for a conversation about his latest collection of verse, At the Foundling Hospital.

Robert is a poet, essayist, literary critic, and translator, and served as Poet Laureate Consultant in Poetry to the Library of Congress. His work has garnered several awards and his latest work promises to be just as deeply moving. Robert will be joined by Red Hen Press authors/poets Tess Taylor and Katharine Coles for a reading and Q&A!

Tess Taylor is the author of The Forage House (Red Hen Press, 2013), finalist for the Believer Poetry Award, and Work & Days (Red Hen Press, 2016). An avid gardener and cook, she dropped out of Amherst College in her twenties to become a translator and chef’s assistant at L’Ecole Ritz Escoffier in Paris. She is currently the on air poetry reviewer for NPR’s All Things Considered.

Katharine Coles is the author of several poetry collections, the most recent of which is Flight (Red Hen Press, 2016); Recent poems and essays have appeared in Virginia Quarterly Review, Poetry, and Crazyhorse. A 2012–13 Guggenheim Fellow, she teaches at the University of Utah.

This event is free to attend.  Copies of Robert's, Tess', and Katherine's books will be available at the event, which takes place in the Rare Book Room, on the 3rd floor of the store at 828 Broadway.
title: Free Readings: Robert Pinsky + Tess Taylor + Katharine Coles

description:
You know her from Broadway and the big screen; now it’s time to hear her story! From losing her first Tony Award to Audra McDonald to twelve-hour car rides for a ten-minute audition, Anna tells all in her collection of autobiographical essays entitled Scrappy Little Nobody.

Join us as Anna celebrates the release of her book at Strand’s Club Monaco location (160 5th Avenue at 21st Street)!

Please Note: Anna will pose for photos, but will not be signing or inscribing books. The books will be signed when you receive them.

This event is sold out. If you'd like to pre-order a signed copy in the event that they become available after the event, you may do so here. This event will take place at Strand’s Club Monaco location (160 5th Avenue at 21st Street). Due to weather conditions and timing limits the standby line is cancelled. Only people who have purchased tickets will be admitted.
title: Anna Kendrick @ Club Monaco

description:
Johnny Marr’s new autobiography, Set the Boy Free, tells the story of one the most influential guitarists and artists of all time. Marr has been constantly pushing musical boundaries in a career that has spanned decades, styles and genres. From co-founding The Smiths with Steven Morrissey, to forming Electronic with Bernard Sumner of New Order to collaborations with The Pretenders, Talking Heads, The The, The Cribs, Hans Zimmer and Modest Mouse, here is a true history of music—told by one of its very own legends.

Johnny will be joined in conversation by Ian Svenonious, vocalist of iconic punk outfit Nation of Ulysses (and others), filmmaker, and author of The Psychic Soviet along with other works.

Tickets are available here. Each ticket purchase includes a copy of Set the Boy Free. This event will take place at the Gramercy Theater, 127 East 23rd Street, New York, NY 10010.
title: Johnny Marr @ Gramercy Theater

description:
Have you ever wondered what wine would pair perfectly with your favorite book? Diane McMartin can help with that. The Certified Sommelier and author of This Calls for a Drink! will be pairing wine with select other Book Riot Live speakers’ books and hosting a discussion and reading with them on Friday, November 11, 7 p.m. at the Strand’s Rare Book Room. Tickets are live now, and include admission to the event, refreshments, and a $15 gift card to the Strand Bookstore!

Featured Authors:

  • Ayize Jama-Everett
  • Tara Clancy
  • Alyssa Cole  

Tickets to this event are $40, include admission, refreshments, and a $15 Strand Gift Card. They can be purchased along with a pass to the Book Riot Live conference. The event will be located in the Strand's 3rd floor Rare Book Room at our store at 828 Broadway at 12th Street.
title: Books & Booze with Diane McMartin and Book Riot Live

description:
It has been called one of the world’s most iconic design books. It was written and designed by Fortunato Depero 90 years ago. Fewer than 1,000 copies were published. Today, very few copies exist that are available for public viewing. Its formal title is Depero Futurista -- which means Depero the Futurist. But it is popularly known as The Bolted Book because it is bound together by two large industrial aluminum bolts. Unbolted, the book can be disassembled and its pages displayed individually.

On Monday, November 14, you will be able to see a copy of this remarkable example of avant-garde bookmaking at a “show and tell” on the second-floor art and design section at the Strand bookstore. If you can’t make it to the Strand you’ll be able to watch live on Kickstarter Live.

The featured speakers will be Laura Mattioli, founder and president of the Center for Italian Modern Art; and Steven Heller, co-founder and co-chair, the School of Visual Arts Design/Designer as Author + Entrepreneur program. Laura will talk about the relationship between Depero and her father, who was one of Depero’s principal patrons. Steven will describe Depero’s place in the history of graphic design and bookmaking.

Then with a copy of the original book from 1927 owned by Laura, Laura and Steven will give a tour through the book -- highlighting key pages and providing insights and commentary on its groundbreaking ideas, pyrotechnic typography, and innovative graphic design. And, of course, the bolts!

This event is free and open to the public and is presented in conjunction with a live Kickstarter campaign to fund publication of a facsimile edition of The Bolted Book.
title: Laura Mattioli + Steven Heller: THE BOLTED BOOK

description:
Author Kevin Baker will take you on an interactive tour of Lower Manhattan which will feature several of the most extraordinary inventions in America the Ingenious, and provide a fascinating look at New York history. You will visit the site where the entire federal government used to be housed in a single, three-storey building; pay your respects at Alexander Hamilton's grave, go inside what was the tallest (and most beautiful) skyscraper in the world for twenty years, check out where all the news was made fit to print, go down to the waterfront, view the damage caused by the worst terrorist attack in the United States before 9/11, learn how the Brooklyn Bridge almost became a catastrophe, and witness the greatest piece of graft in the city's history.

Buy a copy of America the Ingenious or a $15 gift card in-store at the Strand's main floor registers or at the door to attend. This walking tour will meet in the Rare Book Room on the Strand's 3rd floor, accessible via the store elevator or at 826 Broadway.
title: Walking Tour of Lower Manhattan with Kevin Baker: America the Ingenious

description:
The design couple famous for their reality TV makeovers, bringing style tips to eager viewers, are coming to sign their latest style guide! Having seven children of their own makes these two the authorities in making peaceful places in your home. Their iconic relaxed and family-focused style comes full-blast in their latest book all about how to design and decorate your ultimate vacation space or your own home sanctuary.

Join us in the Rare Book Room as Robert and Cortney sign copies of their latest book.

Buy a copy of Beachside Bohemian in-store at the door to attend. This event will take place in the Rare Book Room on the Strand's 3rd floor, accessible via the store elevator or at 826 Broadway.
title: Robert + Cortney Novogratz

description:
The award-winning author has penned an important series of essays focusing on art, feminism, science, and more.

Siri will be in conversation with Jason Tougaw. Jason Tougaw is the author of Touching Brains: Literary Experiments in 21st-Century Neuromania (forthcoming from Yale University Press) and Strange Cases: The Medical Case History of the British Novel. His memoir, The One You Get: Portrait of a Family Organism, is the winner of the 2017 Dzanc Books Nonfiction Prize and will be published by Dzanc next year. He is Associate Professor of English at Queens College and the CUNY Graduate Center.

This event is free and open to the public. Copies of A Woman Looking at Men Looking at Women will be available for purchase at the event. The event will be located in the Strand's 3rd floor Rare Book Room at our store at 828 Broadway at 12th Street.
title: Free Talk: Siri Hustvedt

description:
Mark Seliger is a photographer known for his portraiture, featuring famous actors, artists, and musicians. He served as the lead photographer for Rolling Stone for ten years; however, this collection of never-before-published work features a new group of powerful people. On Christopher Street: Transgender Stories introduces a colorful cast from the trans community including genderqueer, femme, butch, drag kings, drag queens, and more, and their portraits are combined with their personal stories.

Joining Mark is the co-creator of the book, Janet Mock: writer, TV host, transgender rights activist, and author of the New York Times bestseller Redefining Realness. Together they made this powerful piece of art and will both be joining us in the Rare Book Room to celebrate it.

Buy a copy of On Christopher Street or a $15 gift card in-store at the Strand's main floor registers or at the door to attend. This event will take place in the Rare Book Room on the Strand's 3rd floor, accessible via the store elevator or at 826 Broadway.
title: Mark Seliger + Janet Mock

description:
Featuring gentle-hearted Franzen apologist Emily Gould, matress-carrying Emma Sulkowicz, Drake-obsessed power prodigy Jazmine Hughes, radiant legendary wit Hannah Giorgis, man-angering "frisky gal" Katie J.M. Baker, and nervy breakfast expert Kat Kinsman. Hosted by out and proud cat lady Charlotte Shane.

Kat Kinsman is the author of Hi, Anxiety: Life With a Bad Case of Nerves. She is the senior food and drinks editor at Time Inc.’s Extra Crispy, former editor at large and editor in chief of Tasting Table, founding editor of CNN’s Eatocracy and former editor and writer for CNN Living. She’s a frequent public speaker and on-air commentator on the topics of food, drinks and mental health, and started the website chefswithissues.com to provide resources for restaurant workers in crisis. She lives in Brooklyn, NY, with her husband and various animals.

Katie J.M. Baker is a reporter for BuzzFeed News.

Jazmine Hughes is an associate editor at the New York Times Magazine and the founder of Writers of Color, a database that is just what it sounds like. Her work has appeared in The New Yorker, New York, Gawker, The New Republic and elsewhere.

Hannah Giorgis is a culture writer for BuzzFeed News whose work addresses the intersections of race, gender, immigration, class and (pop) culture.

Emily Gould is the co-editor of the Emily Books imprint at Coffee House Press and the author of And The Heart Says Whatever and Friendship.

Emma Sulkowicz lives and makes art in her hometown, New York City. She earned a BFA in Visual Arts from Columbia University in 2015 and is studying studio art in the Whitney Museum Independent Study Program. She is perhaps best known for her senior thesis at Columbia University -- "Mattress Performance (Carry That Weight)" -- an endurance performance artwork in which she carried a dorm mattress everywhere on Columbia's campus for as long as she attended the same school as her attacker. Her more recent works include "Ceci N'est Pas Un Viol," an Internet-based participatory artwork, and "Self-Portrait (Performance With Object)," which was her first solo gallery show. Her awards include the National Organization for Women’s Woman of Courage Award (2016) and Susan B. Anthony Award (2014), the United States Student Association’s National Student Movement Builder of the Year Award (2015), and the Feminist Majority Foundation and Ms. Magazine’s Ms. Wonder Award (2015).

Charlotte Shane is an essayist, author, and co-founded of TigerBee Press. The Guardian likened her written work to Charles Dickens, and Vice called her book Prostitute Laundry "addictive [and] intimate." Just like an opium den. 

Join us in the Rare Book Room for a night of edgy, provocative readings and hilarious, engaging discussions.

Tickets to this event are $10 and include a gift card for the same amout. Tickets are available in-store at the Strand's main floor registers or at the door to attend. This event will take place in the Rare Book Room on the Strand's 3rd floor, accessible via the store elevator or at 826 Broadway.
title: Bad Advice from Bad Women @ Strand - Round 2

description:
Read any history of New York City and you will read about men. You will read about men who were political leaders and men who were activists and cultural tastemakers. These men have been lauded for generations for creating the most exciting and influential city in the world.

But that's not the whole story.

Julie Scelfo’s The Women Who Made New York reveals the untold stories of the phenomenal women who made New York City the cultural epicenter of the world. Many were revolutionaries and activists, like Zora Neale Hurston and Audre Lorde. Others were icons and iconoclasts, like Fran Lebowitz and Grace Jones. There were also women who led quieter private lives but were just as influential, such as Emily Warren Roebling, who completed the construction of the Brooklyn Bridge when her engineer husband became too ill to work. Paired with striking, contemporary illustrations by artist Hallie Heald, The Women Who Made New York offers a visual sensation—one that reinvigorates not just New York City’s history but its very identity.

Join Julie in the epicenter of the bright lights at the heart of the big city itself for a revelatory trip through this “welcome antidote to male-centered history” (David Byrne)! She will be joined in conversation by the book's incredible illustrator, Hallie Heald. Hallie is a freelance illustrator and stylist living and working in New York City. She's worked as an intern for NY designer Nanette Lepore, was an assistant designer and stylist making faux leather handbags, and has been a face painter for fancy birthday parties in Santa Barbara. You can follow her at hehdesignsny.com.

This event is free and open to the public. Buy a copy of The Women Who Made New York in the Strand’s main store or at the Times Square kiosk to have it signed. The event will be located at the Strand’s Times Square kiosk in Duffy Square, between 46th and 47th Streets, Broadway and 7th Avenue.
title: Julie Scelfo: The Women Who Made New York @ Times Square

description:
Join the longest-serving independent in American congressional history, Senator from Vermont and recent presidential candidate Bernie Sanders as he discusses his career and the future of American politics as reflected in his recent best-selling book, Our Revolution: A Future to Believe In.

We are honored to have with us the multi-talented performer, Harry Belafonte with us to introduce Senator Sanders. In addition to his prolific acting and singing career, Mr. Belafonte has acted as a champion for many social and political causes.

No public book signing or photo-op will occur. Please leave all large bags at home.

This event will take place at the Great Hall at Cooper Union, located at 7 E 7th St, New York, NY 10003.

Tickets to this event are sold out.  But you can still catch Bernie's speech thanks to our friends at Huffington Post who will be hosting a FB Live of the event. Like their main facebook page to get notified or tune onto their front page (desktop only) at 8 PM on 12/13.
title: SOLD OUT: Senator Bernie Sanders @ Cooper Union

description:
PUFFS: The Play is hosting a festive Potter affair, just in time to find your honey for the holidays! Guests will play wizardly games and enjoy drinks before embarking on 10 six-minute lightning dates. One lucky matching couple will even win a pair of tickets to PUFFS: The Play for an enchanting first date! Let the adult-butter-beverages flow, and get your flirt on, witch-'n-wizard style.  

Hosts for the night and cast members of the show PUFFS: The Play are:

NICK CARRILLO (J. Finch/Others) has studied sketch/improv at UCB and The PIT, and performs regularly at both theaters. NY credits: West Side Story, MURDER!, South By South Death. TV credits: Hack My Life on truTV, and The Late Show with Jimmy Fallon.

 

JULIE ANN EARLS (Megan) New York: The Mysteries (The Flea). Regional: Romeo and Juliet (Actors' Shakespeare Project). Multiple workshops and readings at Geva Theatre Center, Dixon Place, Provincetown Playhouse, the Musical Theatre Factory, and Target Margin Theater. B.F.A., Boston University.  @julieannearls

This is an event for ages 21-40. Tickets for Witches are SOLD OUT.  A limited number of remaining tickets for Wizards (including a two-for-one deal!) are available in-store, either at the main floor registers or at the door. Ticket includes a $10 Strand Gift Card, unlimited drinks and snacks while supplies last,  and admission to the event. The event will be located in the Strand's 3rd floor Rare Book Room at our store at 828 Broadway at 12th Street.
title: Yule Ball: Speed Dating Edition

description:
Bruce Davidson is a rightful authority in the world of photography. He has been a member of the Magnum Photos agency since 1958, with projects like East 100th Street and The Dwarf. He chronicled the events and effects of the Civil Rights Movement around the country, in both the north and the south, receiving a Guggenheim Fellowship for his efforts. One of his pieces from his Brooklyn Gang collection even ended up on an album cover for Bob Dylan.

Join us in the Rare Book Room as Bruce discusses his work including his latest collection, Survey. Bruce will be joined in conversation with Darius Himes, International Head of Photographs for Christie’s and co-author of Publish Your Photography Book.

Strand is proud to partner with Aperture to celebrate photography.

Bruce will not be signing books following the event. All books for sale at the event are pre-signed by him. Our apologies for any inconvenience. 

Buy a $15 gift card in-store at the door to attend. This event will take place in the Rare Book Room on the Strand's 3rd floor, accessible via the store elevator or at 826 Broadway.
title: Aperture Presents: Bruce Davidson

description:
From New York City to Mississippi, Landgon Clay has traveled the country with his camera in hand, capturing all kinds of beautiful images as well as our imaginations. In the 1970s, Langdon photographed the cars he came across while wandering the streets of New York City and nearby New Jersey at night. Now his focus has turned to those cars with his old photographs of as his muse.

Luc Sante, author of the foreword, will also be available to sign.

Join us in the Second Floor Art Department as Langdon signs his contemplative new collection at Strand!

Copies of Cars: New York City, 1974-1976 will be available for purchase at the event, which will take place in the photography section on the second floor of the Strand at 828 Broadway (at 12th Street).
title: Langdon Clay: CARS

description:
As part of Nitehawk's Harry Potter 20 celebration series, our book store and their movie theatre have teamed up to co-host an epic debate on the ye old question: which is better, the books or the films? Books versus Film: Harry Potter will see two teams face off in a battle royale to the finish line and you will help decide. There will be topics, there will be drinks, and there will be blood.

BOOKS TEAM – THE STRAND

  • ALISE MORALES Alise Morales is a comedy writer and performer based in Brooklyn, NY. She is an improviser on UCBT’s Lloyd Night, and a contributing writer for websites such as Betches and Reductress. You can see her performing all over the city and in festivals across the country.
  • ALIZA WEINBERGER Aliza Weinberger comes to you from the Internet, where she does audience development and books coverage for Mashable.com. She spends her free time on the creative team of Mischief Management, a company that puts on fan conventions including the annual Harry Potter event LeakyCon. One time she wrote a full-length Potter fanfiction play for them about Teddy Lupin.

FILM TEAM – NITEHAWK CINEMA 

  • MATT ZOLLER SEITZ Matt Zoller Seitz is the Editor-in-Chief of RogerEbert.com and the TV critic for New York Magazine and Vulture.com. His writing on film and television has appeared in The New York Times, Salon.com, The New Republic and Sight and Sound. Books include The Wes Anderson Collection, Mad Men Carousel: The Complete Critical Companion, and The Oliver Stone Experience. 
  • MATT JACOBS Matthew Jacobs is an entertainment reporter at The Huffington Post, where he primarily writes about film. A Louisiana native, Matt enjoys Mike Nichols movies, Julia Louis-Dreyfus sitcoms and Madonna minutiae. His favorite “Harry Potter” character is Dobby.

Buy tickets from Nitehawk's website here! Please note that payment is required for all online event orders at the time of checkout. The event will be located in Nitehawk Cinema at 136 Metropolitan Ave, Brooklyn, NY 11249.
title: BOOKS VERSUS FILM: HARRY POTTER

description:
Often cited as the seminal text of modern feminist theory, Simone de Beauvoir’s 1949 publication, The Second Sex still deeply resonates with readers who seek to understand the pervasive oppression of women. The magnum opus of her long and prolific career as a writer and existential philosopher, The Second Sex offers both a sweeping history of women’s subjugation, and a compelling theoretical statement on the nature of being a woman. Women, de Beauvoir argues, are Other. “Humanity,” she writes, “is male and man defines woman not as herself but as relative to him…He is the Subject, the Absolute—she is the Other.”

Jamie Warren has a Ph.D. in American History from Indiana University, and she is an Assistant Professor at BMCC-CUNY where she teaches American history, the history of women and gender, and women’s studies. Her research focuses on slavery in antebellum South with a particular focus on death, the body, and the philosophy of history.

The presenting beer sponsor is Sixpoint Brewery. Wine is generously provided by Maison Cubi. 

Buy a $20 ticket on ThinkOlio’s website or at the door of the event. Ticket includes free drinks while supplies last! Please note that payment is required for all online event orders at the time of checkout. The event will be located in the Strand's 3rd floor Rare Book Room at our store at 828 Broadway at 12th Street.
title: ThinkOlio Presents Woman as Other, Woman as Lover: The Search for Self and the Politics of Love

description:
Doug the Pug is the king of pop culture. More than six million adoring fans on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, and Snapchat can’t get enough of him. Doug spreads love everywhere he goes, and now with his literary debut, he’s coming to living rooms around the world.

It’s hard to find a more well-connected pup than Doug. He’s homies with the hottest stars out there: Justin Bieber, Steven Tyler, Ed Sheeran, John Legend, and Chrissy Teigen, to name just a few. Did you catch him in Fall Out Boy’s latest music video? Doug can ball with the best of them. He’s a rising star and everyone’s favorite squishy face. Doug has made appearances at music festivals including Lollapalooza and the Billboard Hot 100 Music Fest, but he doesn’t let fame go to his head.

Doug is a humble pug, but the people have asked for more, so he’s obliged with King of Pop Culture, his awesome collection of photos. He’ll be at the Strand to take even more with all his fans--don’t miss this chance to see the world-beating champion pug of all things pop culture!

Please Note: No memorabilia other than the book will be permitted at the signing. Also, please do not attempt to feed or pet Doug. Leslie will be signing books, pawtographing on behalf of Doug, and posing for photos with Doug. Each customer is required to purchase a copy of King of Pop Culture at Strand to join the siging line. 

The line will begin to form on Broadway in front of the store at 5:00pm. You will receive a wristband in exchange for proof of purchase, and you will receive a book once inside. Only people with wristbands will be admitted to the signing area. 

Buy a copy of Doug the Pug: King of Pop Culture in-store at the Strand's main floor registers or at the door to attend. The line for the signing is forming on Broadway in front of the Strand at 12th Street.
title: Doug the Pug: The King of Pop Culture

description:
Join us for an evening of board games, delicious treats, and a little friendly competition at Kickstarter’s Game Night. The evening’s agenda will have a literary twist with games featuring celebrated characters and an endless list of pop culture puns. Playtest some upcoming games yet to be released and enjoy some finished Kickstarted games, including Cards Against Humanity and Metagame. From writing outrageous sentences to creating the best romantic fan fiction pairing, here's a roundup of some of our favorite games. Get ready to fill out your scorecard.

Your ticket includes admission, plus delicious cookies provided by Insomnia Cookies, yummy pretzels from Sigmund's, and tasty drinks from Descendent Cider! Treats and drinks are unlimited while supplies last. 

Buy $10 gift card card in-store at the Strand's main floor registers or at the door to attend. This event will take place in the Rare Book Room on the Strand's 3rd floor, accessible via the store elevator or at 826 Broadway.
 

Enjoy the following Kickstarted game projects:

  • Cards Against Humanity by Cards Against Humanity LLC: The wildly popular party game for horrible people will be on hand for you and your most reprehensible friends to build the most outrageous sentences.
  • Slash by Games by Play Date: Compete to create the best romantic fan fiction pairing! Everybody gets a hand of their favorite characters from pop culture, history, and literature. The matchmaker selects one from his or her hand and places it face up on the table. Each player in turn selects a possible 'ship for that character using a card from their hand, narrating as necessary and hoping that the matchmaker chooses theirs. Play continues until one player has accumulated 20 points worth of characters.
  • Papercuts by Electric Literature:  Papercuts is a literary card game for the rude and well-read. It’s what Kurt Vonnegut, James Baldwin, and Virginia Woolf would play if they were alive, locked in a room together, and forced to play a card game. The rules of Papercuts are similar to Cards Against Humanity™, and it can be played on its own or as a bookish expansion pack. Each Papercuts game comes with 75 question cards and 175 answer cards stowed in a neat little box. Order yours now to receive it in time for Christmas, or pick it up from The Strand after December 13!
  • Wordsy by Gil Hova:  A tabletop word game for 1-6 players. It takes only 20 minutes to play, but when you finish, you'll want to play it again. That's because Wordsy is unlike most other word games. In Wordsy, you get 8 letters dealt out on the table. All players simultaneously try to come up with the best word on the board. Here's the thing: you don't need all the letters in your word to be on the board. You can add as many letters as you want! So you're never just one letter away, like in most word games. This means Wordsy rewards longer words. Those 2- and 3-letter words you have to memorize for other word games won't help you here!
  • Moby-Dick, or, the Card Game by King Post: A dynamic and action-packed card game for 2-4 players, lovingly adapted from Herman Melville’s classic novel. Experience the wonders and terrors of 19th century whaling and interact with some of the greatest characters in American literature in a game that's easy to learn but fathoms deep. Assemble your crew, hunt whales and try to survive the final chase for the White Whale!
  • Beowulf by King Post: a dynamic tabletop strategy game for 3-6 players, adapted from one of the oldest and most celebrated works of European literature. The game uses the Anglo-Saxon epic poem as a point of entry into a vast interpretation of the Viking Age. As the legend of Beowulf's life and death unfolds on the game's board, players will trade, scheme and raid one another to grow their own kingdom's influence and power. After the death of Beowulf at the fangs of a dragon, the game moves forward in time, as players scramble to preserve the brave legacies of their kingdoms in the face of a quickly changing religious landscape and the relentless tides of history.
  • Metagame by Local No. 12: A party game about sharing opinions on the most important debates of our time, like "which feels more like first love: The Mona Lisa or the Big Mac?" The Metagame includes culture cards that feature media, art, fashion and entertainment, and opinion cards that prompt lively chatter and lots of laughter. The Metagame is more than one game—it includes six unique games. Some of the games get you talking. Others are about thinking fast. Some games are strategic and others are just plain silly. Including 200 culture cards and 100 opinion cards, The Metagame scales from two to 50 players. Play it at a dinner party or a family gathering, at a bar or at school, or anywhere that humans gather.
  • Bring Your Own Book by Do Better Games: The game of borrowed phrases, where players search through books for text to take way out of context. It's easy. Players take turns drawing prompts from the deck, then race to find the best phrase in their own book that satisfies the prompt. Since you can use a different book each time, you can play it with any audience, and there's a practically infinite supply of source material.
title: Game Night Brought to You by Kickstarter

description:
Thousands of people have been fleeing their war-torn countries, searching for safety, for a place to protect their families, for a home. They will search for escape by any means necessary, often risking their own lives to find it. Few people outside of the mass of refugees can truly understand their flight, their fear, their disregard of danger; however, Patrick Kingsley, the Guardian’s first-ever migration correspondent, chose to try and understand those fleeing. Patrick followed several groups of people running from the destruction of their homelands as they ventured across unsafe waters and weather conditions, joining them in their struggle to better understand their world. He has written their stories, capturing their tragedy in the written word, and is here to share them with us.

Joining Patrick in conversation is Manal Kahi, founder of Eat Offbeat – a catering company that delivers authentic ethnic meals that are conceived, prepared and delivered by refugees resettled in NYC.

Ben Taub, contributing writer for the New Yorker, will moderate the discussion. 

Copies of The New Odyssey will be available for purchase at the event. The event will be located in the Rare Book Room on the Strand's 3rd floor at our store at 828 Broadway at 12th Street.

Praise for THE NEW ODYSSEY :

  • “Combining deep research, globe-spanning journalism, and a poetic ethos the subject cries out for, Patrick Kingsley has written the essential work on the refugee crisis in Europe.”—Molly Crabapple, author of Drawing Blood
  • “Kingsley intimately covers the issues, struggles, and stories of migrant refugees. . . . [The New Odyssey] is deeply engaging, eye-opening, and insightful to the ongoing challenges that refugees face in navigating through these multilayers political and social systems.” —Raymond Pun, Booklist
  • “Bravely following the refugee crisis from the Middle East to the European Union as it gains volume and urgency. . . . Kingsley takes both a personal and altruistic approach to the massive migration of peoples fleeing Syria and other global hot spots. . . . A powerful firsthand account of a crisis that will continue to receive even more attention in the years to come.” —Kirkus Reviews, starred review
title: FREE TALK: Patrick Kingsley and Manal Kahi

description:
A decade has passed since boots first hit the ground in Iraq and Afghanistan. Yet the war has not ended?only changed. Twenty-five diverse veteran voices reflect the changing face of combat and reflect the haunting realities and truths only fiction can reveal.

Join a panel of experienced fictioneers, up-and-comers, and everyone in between, all pulled from the ranks of America's armed forces, as they discuss their stories in The Road Ahead: Stories of the Forever War, a "shockingly brilliant salvo in the next wave of literature about our perpetual wars" (Phil Klay), edited by Adrian Bonenberger and Brian Castner. These masterfully crafted stories from writers who have served reflect the entire breadth of human emotion?loss, anger, joy, love, fear, and courage?and the evolving nature of what has become America’s “Forever War.” Don't miss this opportunity to hear readings of and conversations about these masterful stories.

Moderating the conversation will be NYC's Veterans Affairs Commissioner Loree Sutton. Featured panelists from the book will include Kristen Rouse, Chris Wolfe, Elliot Ackerman, Teresa Fazio, along with Brian Castner, the anthology's editor.

Buy a copy of The Road Ahead or a $15 gift card in-store at the Strand's main floor registers or at the door to attend. This event will take place in the Rare Book Room on the Strand's 3rd floor, accessible via the store elevator or at 826 Broadway.
title: The Road Ahead: Stories from the Forever War

description:
In 1985 Terry Anderson was abducted from a street in Beirut, put into the trunk of a car, and kept as a hostage for almost seven years. While he was fortunate enough to be released and reunited with his family, including his six-year-old daughter Sulome, he was changed. Haunted by his time as a hostage, Terry turned to the false promise of comfort with drugs. Sulome watched as her father struggled with drug abuse and mental illness. Years went by and Sulome decided to travel to the Middle East in hopes of understanding what drove her father to this. From this was born a beautifully crafted mix of a memoir and a journey to understand her father.

Join us in the Rare Book Room as Sulome tells the story of her travels, her father, and how this process of discovery has changed her. She will be interviewed by Paul Wood, BBC foreign correspondent most recently based in Beirut covering Syria.

Buy a copy of The Hostage's Daughter or a $15 gift card in-store at the Strand's main floor registers or at the door to attend. This event will take place in the Rare Book Room on the Strand's 3rd floor, accessible via the store elevator or at 826 Broadway.
 

Sulome Anderson has been working as a feature writer in the Middle East since receiving a master’s degree from Columbia University’s Graduate School of Journalism. She’s covered topics ranging from Syrian refugee suicides to the war against ISIS for magazines including Foreign Policy, Vox, The Atlantic, New York Magazine, and VICE. She is based in Beirut and New York City.

Paul Wood has been a BBC foreign correspondent for more than 20 years, most recently based in Beirut and covering Syria. He was smuggled over the border many times to report on the Syrian uprising and civil war. He received the US Radio and TV Correspondents’ Association David Bloom award for foreign reporting twice, in 2012 and 2015. His Syria reporting has also won two US Emmys, a Peabody, a Sony Gold, and the Royal Television Society’s international coverage award. He was the UK Foreign Press Association’s journalist of the year. He was a Fall 2015 fellow at the Shorenstein Center in the Kennedy School of Government, Harvard. He has just completed a documentary on the Western hostages murdered by the “Islamic State”.
title: Sulome Anderson

description:
From eSports events drawing thousands of spectators to Candy Crush players killing time on the subway, the world of gaming has expanded drastically in recent years. Of course, as with any other mainstream form of entertainment, video games have become the spotlight of several criticisms as politicians, media, and parents wonder about the effects they have on those who play. After years of research, it turns out video games have a lot of good to offer, besides hours of fun.

Games for Change chairman Asi Burak and journalist Laura Parker decided to explore how video games pioneer social change, how the stories games feature can focus on social and political issues in an immersive way that other art forms can’t capture. They have worked with NASA, World Bank, the White House, and The United Nations in order to promote the positive effects of gaming.

Join us in the Rare Book Room as Asi Burak talks with Susanna Pollack, President of Games for Change, about how video games can change the future. After the discussion, both Asi Burak and Laura Parker will sign copies of their book.

Buy a copy of Power Play or a $15 gift card in-store at the Strand's main floor registers or at the door to attend. This event will take place in the Rare Book Room on the Strand's 3rd floor, accessible via the store elevator or at 826 Broadway.
 

Asi Burak was named one of the “Digital 25: Leaders in Emerging Entertainment” by the Producers Guild of America (PGA) and Variety Magazine for his work with Games for Change. Before Games for Change, Burak co-founded and led Impact Games, the creators of the acclaimed PeaceMaker and Play the News.

Laura Parker is a journalist based in New York. She contributes short and longform pieces to The New York Times, The New Yorker, Vanity Fair, Rolling Stone and The Atlantic.

Susanna Pollack is the President of Games for Change, the leading global advocate for the power of games as drivers of social impact. In her role there, Susanna produces the annual Games for Change Festival, the largest industry facing gaming event in New York, runs educational programs, game design challenges and acts as a consultant with NGO’s, foundations and government agencies.
title: Power Play: How Video Games Can Save the World

description:
Science fiction allows us the room to imagine what it looks like when alien races come up against one another and, namely, our human race. The genre’s power is in the ability to cloak our human frailties, ugliness, triumphs, and beauty in an alien package for audiences to open and revel in, grapple with. Little are we necessarily conscious of how thin and permeable the membrane between fiction and reality actually is. 

We will look at the Borg of Star Trek lore and seek to identify their ultimate goal of assimilation with the sort of assimilation that occurs in the everyday lives of immigrant communities and communities of color. What happens when you live multiple lives in order to survive? Who is your authentic self? And when your outer identity—namely race—is assimilated by the culture at large, what are the consequences of your inner identity’s mismatch? 

Clare Kendry is Nella Larsen’s embodiment of how explosive these consequences can be in her novel, Passing. We will look at Clare as another fictional example and talk about mental health concerns regarding the very real and ongoing struggle between being one of them and being who you are. It is imperative to have a conversation acknowledging racial division and colorism in order to explain fully why not all people have have these devisive experiences and more importantly, to understand why these experiences exist.

Patricia Kim received her MFA from Columbia University and has been teaching College Composition and Literature classes at Baruch College and around NY while completing a novel. Her experience working with disadvantaged youth at the college level inspired her to pursue an MSW at Columbia.

The presenting beer sponsor is Sixpoint Brewery. Wine is generously provided by Maison Cubi. 

Buy a ticket HERE or at the door to attend. This event will take place in the Rare Book Room on the Strand's 3rd floor, accessible via the store elevator or at 826 Broadway.
title: ThinkOlio Presents: Being One of Them and Being Who You Are: The Immigrant's Search for an Authentic Self

description:
Bustle Books editor Cristina Arreola and Juliet Takes A Breath author Gabby Rivera lead the inaugural meeting of Bustle's American Woman Book Club.

Reading has been proven to promote empathy, and Bustle believes that reading broadly is one small step in mending the divides of our nation. In 2017, join we'll read books by women of all different backgrounds, races, ethnicities, social classes, religions, and sexualities. Join Bustle Books Editor Cristina Arreola and author Gabby Rivera for a conversation about the book club's January selection: Juliet Takes A Breath.

This event is free and open to the public, and will take place on the second floor in the store at 828 Broadway at 12th Street. Purchase your copy of Juliet Takes a Breath at the Strand to get it signed.
title: Bustle's American Woman Book Club With Gabby Rivera

description:
An evening celebrating the launch of Eye Level, a new literary lifestyle publication co-created by Caroline Donofrio and Uli Beutter Cohen. The evening will feature readings of favorite book passages, given by authors and literary New Yorkers. Join us and join the conversation! This event is free of charge and open to the public.

Caroline Donofrio is a writer and editor residing in Brooklyn. Previously, she worked as an editor at Penguin Random House. Caroline is the author of a forthcoming series of middle grade books (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, 2018) and is also at work on a novel.

Uli Beutter Cohen is the creator of Subway Book Review (@subwaybookreview) and has worked in digital media as a content creator for the past decade. Clients include Nike, Prabal Gurung, Ace Hotel, Interscope and more. She lives in Brooklyn with her husband and cat. One of them is a comedy writer.

Caroline & Uli's work has been featured by Vogue, The Guardian, Refinery29, The Huffington Post, the BBC, The Atlantic, Village Voice, Bustle, A Cup of Jo, HelloGiggles, Cherry Bombe, and more.

This event is free and open to the public. Please RSVP here to confirm your spot-- seats are limited! The event will be located in the Strand's 3rd floor Rare Book Room at our store at 828 Broadway at 12th Street.
title: Eye Level Launch Party

description:
The unforgettable characters in Josh Barkan’s astonishing and beautiful story collection Mexico—chef, architect, nurse, high school teacher, painter, beauty queen, classical bass player, plastic surgeon, businessman, mime—are simply trying to lead their lives and steer clear of violence. Yet, inevitably, crime has a way of intruding on their lives all the same. A surgeon finds himself forced into performing a risky procedure on a narco killer. A teacher struggles to protect lovestruck students whose forbidden romance has put them in mortal peril. A painter’s freewheeling ways land him in the back of a kidnapper’s car. Again and again, the walls between “ordinary life” and cartel violence are shown to be paper thin, and when they collapse the consequences are life-changing. 

These are stories about transformation and danger, passion and heartbreak, terror and triumph. They are funny, deeply moving, and stunningly well-crafted, and they tap into the most universal and enduring human experiences:  love even in the face of danger and loss, the struggle to grow and keep faith amidst hardship and conflict, and the pursuit of authenticity and courage over apathy and oppression. With unflinching honesty and exquisite tenderness, Josh Barkan masterfully introduces us to characters that are full of life--join us on the Strand's second floor for a reading from this collection, and mark the arrival of a uniquely assured and essential voice in American fiction.

Copies of Mexico will be available for purchase at the event. The event will take place in the photography section on the second floor of the Strand at 828 Broadway (at 12th Street).

Additional Praise for MEXICO:

“Mexico is a remarkable achievement. It is a portrait of a nation told from an astonishing range of characters, examining their daily lives in the wake of the violence created by the drug cartels. With great authority and compassion, Josh Barkan explores the human cost of this violence, looking at this world with an eye that is both uncompromising and tender. The stories are beautiful, funny, and terrifying; Barkan has created a collection that is utterly riveting and necessary. This is fiction of the highest order; read it now.” — Karen Bender, author of Refund (National Book Award Finalist, 2015)

 “Mexico is a poignant and original collection of stories. ‘In Mexico, everything’s about excess’ a narrator explains, and Josh Barkan proves this truth at every turn. He also reminds us that short stories, when beautifully written, are never short.” — Jennifer Clement, author of Prayers for the Stolen (PEN/Faulkner Award Finalist, 2015)

“Macabre, outrageously funny, touching, and irresistibly readable, the stories in this collection depict with boldness the complexity, and madness, of contemporary Mexican society. The ensemble of diverse voices narrating these tales is mind-blowing. We have here the work of an original, terrifying, and spectacularly gifted storyteller.” — Jaime Manrique, author of Cervantes Street

 “‘Do you think you can stomach such a story?’ one woman asks another in Mexico, Josh Barkan’s impressive new collection. He possesses the skill, nerve, and compassion to tell unforgettable stories from across the border, stories that are by turns violent, tender, heart-breaking, haunted, and surprising, rendered with such exacting care that readers will answer that question with a resounding Yes.” — Christopher Merrill, author of The Tree of the Doves: Ceremony, Expedition, War; director of the International Writing Program at the University of Iowa

 “Mexico is a marvel. Josh Barkan has created a suite of stories that are beautiful and harrowing, wise and comic. His heroes, mostly American expats who have headed south to reinvigorate their lives, are continually cast into danger and forced to reckon with the darkness that lives around them, and within them. And yet, the wonder of these stories is their ability to guide us through this rough terrain without descending into cynicism. As readers, and humans, we are inspired by these tales to ‘sing in some way of beauty, to raise the spirit of our voices in hope.’” — Steve Almond, author of The Evil B.B. Chow and Other Stories and Candyfreak

 “Raw, strange, beautiful, the stories bring us into the heart of a very dangerous country, which is Mexico, and something else, which is ourselves.” — Peter Behrens, author of Carry Me (winner of the 2006 Governor General’s Award, Canada)

 “Barkan’s collection will thrill anyone curious about what goes on behind closed doors in contemporary Mexico. These tales mic the seductive voices of the marginal and lost. With a ventriloquist’s skill, Barkan gets his speakers to lure you up surprising steps: toward a sacrificial plateau where anyone might steal your heart, including the notorious drug lord El Chapo as well as your neighborhood soldier and corner prostitute. Barkan’s prose is empathic and lucid in stories too fantastic to be anything but real.” — Edie Meidav, author of Kingdom of the Young and Lola, California
title: Josh Barkan: Mexico

description:
In an era when real estate developers preach the power of art to change society, and when innovative capitalist design has come to be called art, one has to appreciate—and perhaps foster a healthy suspicion of—just how far art has come.

In Culture as Weapon: The Art of Influence in Everyday Life, activist, curator, and critic Nato Thompson asks us to see the culture wars as more than just Reagan-era history, but as part of an evolving assault that uses art and affect to appeal to our emotional selves. In a sweeping account, he connects the innovative public relations strategies developed in the early 20th-century by Edward Bernays, Ivy Lee, and others to modern-day phenomena as diverse as urban development, public art, charitable giving, and even the U.S. military?s battle for “hearts and minds” in the Middle East.

The result is a spirited and insightful examination of how, over the past century, corporations, politicians, nonprofits, and activists alike have embraced the power of creativity to shape public opinion, for good and for ill. Thompson simultaneously investigates the way artists have reacted to this cultural transformation, from Andy Warhol's prescient Pop Art to Dread Scott Tyler's provocative installations to Suzanne Lacy's social interventions. As he puts it, “the world has witnessed the realization of the age-old avant-garde demand that art become part of the everyday.”

Join Nato as he discusses his research and practice at the intersection of power and culture with critic/curator Christian Viveros-Fauné.

 

Buy a copy of Culture as Weapon or a $15 gift card in-store at the Strand's main floor registers or at the door to attend. This event will take place in the Rare Book Room on the Strand's 3rd floor, accessible via the store elevator or at 826 Broadway.
 

Nato Thompson is Artistic Director at the New York City public arts organization Creative Time. He is the editor of Experimental Geography: Radical Approaches to Landscape, Cartography, and Urbanism (Melville House); The Interventionists: Users' Manual for the Creative Disruption of Everyday Life; and Living as Form: Socially Engaged Art from 1991–2011. His most recent book is Seeing Power: Art and Activism in the 21st Century (Melville House). (Photo: Derek Schultz)

 

Christian Viveros-Fauné is a New York-based writer and curator, and a former art dealer and art fair director (VOLTA and NEXT). Currently Art and Culture Critic at artnet News, he has written for Art in America, Artnews, The Baffler, Departures, and Frieze, among other publications. He is editor of Darío Escobar: The Life of the Object (Lucia | Marquand, January 2017). (Photo: Ari Espay)
title: Nato Thompson: Culture as Weapon

description:
From the birth of jazz in New Orleans to the spread of drugs in Harlem, the culture of music and drugs has been a tale of mutually informative symbiosis. From their introduction to America through the personalities, performances, and writings of the Beats, among others, recreational drugs have taken root in and taken their toll on creators like the jazz innovators of the mid-20th century. Author Martin Torgoff weaves together this history of drugs, jazz, and race in a beautiful, smooth fashion, as it's never been told before.

Martin is joined by John Tytell for a conversation about the long, strange trip of music.

Buy a copy of Bop Apocalypse or a $15 gift card in-store at the Strand's main floor registers or at the door to attend. This event will take place in the Rare Book Room on the Strand's 3rd floor, accessible via the store elevator or at 826 Broadway.
title: Bop Apocalypse

description:
Eisenhower cautioned us against the military one; if only Orson Welles had warned us about the vastly more insidious assemblage, the Entertainment-Industrial Complex. Reality has become much less real (and less important) in contemporary American society. America is a country that came of age with Industrialization and was accompanied by the creation of a mass media public sphere. More often than is desirable, people’s favorite binge show is more important to them than what goes on in the real world. How does this retreat into a fantasy world evidence itself in our real world politics today? Let's talk about how fantasy has bled into reality and try to understand what it means for the future of our country.

Dr. J. Ward Regan has a Ph.D. in Labor and Cultural History from the State University of New York at Stony Brook. He teaches history and philosophy at New York University Liberal Studies and Global Liberal Studies Program. He wrote and widely performed his own show, A Paranoid’s Guide to History.

The presenting beer sponsor is Sixpoint Brewery. Wine is generously provided by Maison Cubi. 

Buy a ticket HERE or at the door to attend. This event will take place in the Rare Book Room on the Strand's 3rd floor, accessible via the store elevator or at 826 Broadway.
title: ThinkOlio Presents: Inside the Entertainment-Industrial Complex: How Guilty Pleasures Take the Edge Off Reality

description:
Jason Diamond set out to write a biography of his favorite filmmaker John Hughes and ended up creating his own touching memoir.

Joining Jason in conversation is fellow 80s movie enthusiast Kevin Smokler, author of the book Brat Pack America: A Love Letter to '80s Teen Movies.

Join us up in the Rare Book Room as we screen clips from 80s movies and have a movie night themed party!

Buy a copy of Searching for John Hughes or a $15 gift card in-store at the Strand's main floor registers or at the door to attend. This event will take place in the Rare Book Room on the Strand's 3rd floor, accessible via the store elevator or at 826 Broadway.
title: Jason Diamond + Kevin Smokler

description:
This panel discussion on the conceptual, editorial, design, and production processes behind the exhibition catalogue Tales of Our Time features exhibition curator Xiaoyu Weng; Julian Myers-Szupinska, California College of the Arts; Brian Kuan Wood, e-flux; and Chris Wu, Project Projects. It is moderated by Lisa Naftolin, Creative Director, Publishing and Digital Media at the Guggenheim. The evening includes a reading from the catalogue by Brian Kuan Wood, book signing, and light reception.

A conceptual extension of the exhibition Tales of Our Time, the catalogue edited by Xiaoyu Weng and Hou Hanru blends a traditional museum publication with a fiction anthology. Featuring scholarly essays and artwork descriptions, it unconventionally examines the exhibition artists and challenges current views about art from China. Interwoven with these essays are seven commissioned short stories by Chinese and American fiction writers Han Song, Hon Lai-chu, Li Juan, Ken Liu, Lo Yi-chin, Wang Bang, and Brian Kuan Wood. The exhibition and accompanying catalogue offer a heterogeneous view of contemporary art and culture from China, highlighting tensions between individual narratives and mainstream history as well as exploring how the gaps between the two can be transcended.

Buy a copy of Tales of Our Time or a $20 gift card in-store at the Strand's main floor registers or at the door to attend. This event will take place in the Rare Book Room on the Strand's 3rd floor, accessible via the store elevator or at 826 Broadway.
 

Panelists:

  • Julian Myers-Szupinska is an art historian based in Oakland and Los Angeles. He is an associate professor at California College of the Arts (CCA), San Francisco, a member (with Joanna Szupinska) of the curatorial collaboration grupa o.k., and is Senior Editor of The Exhibitionist, a journal of exhibition-making.
  • Xiaoyu Weng is The Robert H. N. Ho Family Foundation Associate Curator of Chinese Art at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum and exhibition curator of Tales of Our Time. She served as the founding director of the Kadist Art Foundation’s Asia Programs, Paris and San Francisco. Previously, she worked as program director of the Asian Contemporary Art Consortium and as a curator at the Wattis Institute for Contemporary Arts at CCA, both in San Francisco. Educated at the Central Academy of Fine Arts (CAFA) in Beijing and CCA, she has organized exhibitions and public programs for venues including the Asian Art Museum of San Francisco; CAFA Art Museum, Beijing; and Witte de With Center for Contemporary Art, Rotterdam; among others. She is a contributing editor of Leap, a bilingual magazine dedicated to contemporary Chinese art. Her writing also appears in prominent art periodicals, books, and exhibition catalogues, including those published for the 2012 Gwangju Biennial, 2012 Shenzhen Sculpture Biennial, and 2013 Auckland Triennial.
  • Brian Kuan Wood is a writer based in New York. He is an editor of e-flux journal.
  • Chris Wu is Associate Principal at Project Projects, where he leads identity, print, interactive and environmental projects for clients such as the Guggenheim Museum, Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York; Pew Center for Arts & Heritage, Philadelphia; Asia Art Archive, Hong Kong; Modern Media Group, Shanghai; and M+/West Kowloon Cultural District Authority, Hong Kong. With his bilingual and multicultural background, Chris has lectured and served as a guest critic at universities and institutions internationally; he has also led a workshop on Chinese typography at the Type Directors Club in New York. In 2008 Wu authored, translated, edited, and designed a reissued edition of Graphic Design: Visual Comparisons (Zoar Press), the iconic design title originally published in 1963. His work has been widely published in design publications such as IDEA (Japan), Eye (UK), City Magazine (Hong Kong), PPaper (Taiwan), and Design 360? (China). Chris received his master’s degree in communications design at Pratt Institute, Brooklyn.

Moderator:

Lisa Naftolin is Creative Director, Publishing and Digital Media at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. She has worked on commercial and cultural projects for brands, magazines, museums, and individuals for the past 25 years. Having begun her career designing books and exhibition materials for contemporary art and experimental film, Naftolin has also worked as an art director at publications including the New York Times Magazine and Architecture. She was previously Creative Director of Art + Commerce and Executive Director of Creative Brand Development at NARS Cosmetics. The recipient of numerous professional awards, Naftolin has sat on the board of the American Institute for Graphic Arts (AIGA), New York, and on juries for the AIGA and the Hyères Festival, among others. She has been a visiting critic in design at Yale University, New Haven; a visiting artist at Cooper Union, New York; and a mentor in the photography program at the School of Visual Arts, New York.

This program is made possible by The Robert H. N. Ho Family Foundation.
title: The Guggenheim Presents: The Making of Tales of Our Time

description:
Sometimes you gotta treat yo' self to some time with your best gal pals... So come on out and hand with these awesome and inspirational Geek Gals you poetic, noble land mermaid!

  • Che Grayson is a Brooklyn-based filmmaker, comic book creator and former TED resident. She's currently in development for her feature film debut, Red Bones. @FandomFox ,

  • Yissel Ayala is a Co-Founder of Geek Girl Brunch, Brooklyn native, blogger and designer at TheDesignerGeek.com. @TheDesignerGeek

description:
Genet…Beckett…Burroughs…Miller…Ionesco... Duras. Harold Pinter and Tom Stoppard. Hubert Selby Jr. and John Rechy. The legendary film I Am Curious (Yellow). The books that assaulted the fort of propriety that was the United States in the 1950s and ’60s, Lady Chatterley’s Lover and The Tropic of Cancer. The Evergreen Review. Victorian “erotica.” The Autobiography of Malcolm X. A bombing, a sit-in, and a near-fistfight with Norman Mailer. The common thread between these disparate elements, a number of which reshaped modern culture, was Barney Rosset.

His unswerving dedication to publishing what he wanted made him one of the most influential publishers ever. At times appalling, more often inspiring, never boring or conventional: this is Barney Rosset, uncensored.

Joining us to discuss the impact Rosset had on the publishing industry as we know it: Dale Peck, A.M. Homes, Lev Grossman, and Emily Gould.

Buy a copy of Rosset or a $15 gift card in-store at the Strand's main floor registers or at the door to attend. This event will take place in the Rare Book Room on the Strand's 3rd floor, accessible via the store elevator or at 826 Broadway.
title: MY LIFE IN PUBLISHING AND HOW I FOUGHT CENSORSHIP

description:

description:

In his new book he shows that the companionship between people and their pets is a bond like no other. This book features various clients and their canine friends from celebrities to the everyday dog lover and shares eight essential lessons he’s learned through the decades of work.

Join us in the Rare Book Room as we celebrate the launch of Cesar's new book with a talk and a signing!

While we all love our canine companions, please be sure to leave them at home.

Buy a copy of Lessons from the Pack or a $15 gift card in-store at the Strand's main floor registers or at the door to attend. This event will take place in the Rare Book Room on the Strand's 3rd floor, accessible via the store elevator or at 826 Broadway.
title: Cesar Millan

description:
The award-winning and masterful writer has written for New York Times and now writes for The New Yorker, Esquire, and various other publications. He is credited with establishing literary journalism and expanding the genre of creative non-fiction. This new collection features the articles he penned that went on to become his wonderful books.

Buy a copy of High Notes or a $15 gift card in-store at the Strand's main floor registers or at the door to attend. This event will take place in the Rare Book Room on the Strand's 3rd floor, accessible via the store elevator or at 826 Broadway.
title: Gay Talese

description:
The average American living in the digital age willingly hands over dozens of snippets of very personal information to a host of strangers on a daily basis. Sometimes knowingly, but more oftentimes not. Those snippets are then recorded, reconfigured, and redistributed in ways that few people really understand. The United States presently has the weakest information privacy laws among all of the advanced democracies.

How did we get here? Why didn't we see this coming?

This lecture examines the history of large-scale data collection in America from the first census in 1790 to the present day. Topics will include the rise of the welfare state, the advent of mainframe computers, early social and political debates over data privacy and protection, the many problems inherent to the misuse of personal data, and what privacy advocates are presently doing about all this. Front-and-center will be an examination of the all too familiar statement: “If you’re doing nothing wrong then you should have nothing to hide.”

Leading this lecture is Lawrence Cappello, historian and privacy advocate. He is the director of quantitative research at the CUNY Center of Latino Studies and a lecturer of United States history at CUNY Queens College. He has written for The Atlantic and The Nation.

The presenting beer sponsor is Sixpoint Brewery. Wine is generously provided by Maison Cubi. 

Buy a ticket HERE or at the door to attend. This event will take place in the Rare Book Room on the Strand's 3rd floor, accessible via the store elevator or at 826 Broadway.
title: ThinkOlio Presents Privacy and the Profit Motive: “If you’re not doing anything wrong then you should have nothing to hide.”

description:
